title: SHIP Medicare-Only Q3: Traditional Medicare vs Medicare Advantage Comparison
description: SHIP mystery-shopper study Question #3 from Medicare-Only scenario (eAppendix 1). Tests ability to explain differences between Medicare Advantage and Original Medicare.
source: Dugan K et al. JAMA Network Open. 2025;8(4):e252834 - eAppendix 1, Question #3

persona.current_coverage: Employer-based health coverage with prescription drug coverage
persona.situation: Turning 65 in 2 months, just becoming eligible for Medicare (aging in). Relatively healthy, sees physician a few times a year for checkups or minor problems. Takes Lipitor 10mg daily for cholesterol. Not on Medicaid and does not qualify for it. Has received Medicare card but doesn't have it readily available. Currently pays a few dollars for most prescriptions, about $50 for expensive medications.

scripted_turns.user_message: I keep hearing about Medicare Advantage. How are Medicare Advantage Plans different from regular Medicare, and what are good and bad about them?
expected_topics: Medicare Advantage: lower costs, network restrictions, cannot keep doctor, covers Part A/B/D, still pay Part B premium, extra benefits

Original Medicare: automatic Part A enrollment, optional Part B, Part A has deductible but no premium, Part B has premium and deductible, costs can be higher, choose any provider, need separate Part D, can pair with Medigap

canonical_facts.statement: Medicare Advantage plans may have lower premiums, deductibles, and cost sharing than Traditional Medicare plus a Supplement plan.
canonical_facts.rationale: Key cost advantage of MA plans for some beneficiaries

canonical_facts.statement: Medicare Advantage plans have a more restrictive choice of providers and hospitals compared to Original Medicare.
canonical_facts.rationale: Major limitation of MA plans - network restrictions

canonical_facts.statement: You may not be able to keep your current doctor with a Medicare Advantage plan.
Medicare Advantage plans cover all Medicare Part A and Part B benefits, and sometimes Part D (prescription drug) benefits.
canonical_facts.rationale: MA plans must cover at minimum everything Original Medicare covers

canonical_facts.statement: With a Medicare Advantage plan, you must continue to pay the Medicare Part B premium in addition to the Medicare Advantage Plan premium.
canonical_facts.rationale: Common misunderstanding - Part B premium still required

canonical_facts.statement: Medicare Advantage plans often offer additional benefits such as vision, hearing, dental, fitness, grocery benefits, or over-the-counter (OTC) card.
canonical_facts.rationale: Common extra benefits that attract enrollees to MA plans

canonical_facts.statement: You automatically enroll in Medicare Part A when you apply for Medicare, which provides coverage for hospital stays.
canonical_facts.rationale: Fundamental structure of Original Medicare enrollment

canonical_facts.statement: You have the option to enroll in Medicare Part B to cover doctors' services, outpatient care, and preventative services.
canonical_facts.rationale: Part B is optional but covers essential outpatient services

canonical_facts.statement: Medicare Part A has a deductible and some cost sharing but no monthly premium for most people.
canonical_facts.rationale: Important cost structure detail for Part A

canonical_facts.statement: Medicare Part B has a monthly premium, some cost sharing, and a small deductible.
canonical_facts.rationale: Important cost structure detail for Part B

canonical_facts.statement: Original Medicare premiums and cost sharing can be more expensive than with Medicare Advantage Plans, especially without supplemental coverage.
With Original Medicare, you have your choice of almost any provider or hospital that accepts Medicare.
canonical_facts.rationale: Key advantage of Original Medicare - no network restrictions

canonical_facts.statement: In order to receive coverage for prescription drugs with Original Medicare, you must obtain a separate Prescription Drug Plan (Part D).
canonical_facts.rationale: Critical gap in Original Medicare that requires additional enrollment

canonical_facts.statement: Original Medicare can be paired with a Medigap (Medicare Supplement) policy to reduce premiums, deductibles, and cost sharing.
canonical_facts.rationale: Common strategy to manage Original Medicare out-of-pocket costs

disallowed_claims: Claiming one option is objectively better than the other without qualifying with 'it depends on individual circumstances'
Stating specific plan premiums or copays without performing a lookup
Claiming specific doctors are in-network for a specific plan without verification
Advising to enroll in a specific plan type without understanding individual needs and preferences
acceptable_referrals: Medicare.gov Plan Finder for comparing specific plans
State Health Insurance Assistance Program (SHIP) for local counseling
Recommend speaking with a licensed insurance agent
Suggest discussing with primary care physician about network participation

score_3.label: Not Substantive
score_3.criteria: Response does not substantively discuss any MA or TM points
